content: Hey @Wesley Wiser , I wanted to check in with you about something
:wave:
so in the wake of the 1.52.0 + 1.52.1 fingerprint stuff

one thing that I’ve seen at AWS is this process called a “Correction Of Error”, where, in response to a service incident, after the problem is fixed, they spend a while documenting what led to the problem in the first place
cc @Carl Lerche
I’m planning to propose that the compiler-team craft such a document
i.e., I’ll put up a proposal for this Friday’s planning meeting, that one of the subsequent steering meetings be dedicated to reviewing such a document
mostly the intention is to take a look at our internal processes, and figure out what we can improve, especially through automation/tooling, to try to reduce risk of a similar event in future
I am planning to be involved in crafting the doc. I don’t know yet if it makes sense for me to try to write it on my own.
That seems like a great idea to me! Do we first need a retro to determine what went wrong or do you think we've covered that enough already?
I mostly wanted to give you a heads up, and give you a chance to think about your availability to assist
I can definitely make time to help

In terms of determining what went wrong, I believe that between the model I have in my head, plus the zulip logs, I should be able to retrace steps without needing a synchronous meeting dedicated to determination
I do think that reaching out to people and getting their input is part of this document
but I think that will work best asynchronously, potentially even via 1:1 privmsg's
FWIW release has done something on its end like this already, with several proposals made (some implemented)
ah cool
I’ll make sure to review those discussions, I assume they are all in zulip
One really important point I’ve noticed about the AWS process
yeah they're on zulip
https://github.com/rust-lang/release-team/issues also, a little
is that while they will explain where things went wrong, the documents are not about assigning blame
instead, its about identifying opportunities for improvement, and also about understanding what tradeoff calculations were made along the way
Yeah, I think that would be very useful in this situation
Depending on how we capture the results, we may want to publish it more broadly to show the community how seriously we're taking it.
filed as https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/435
